content.description: This line starts in a crack that is of good rock,  however as you move up there are bands of poor quality both right and left.  Stay in the crack which remains good. Gear is solid and the edges have been scrubbed.  The face moves at the top are fun!
content.protection: BD .3 - 3.0 X 1, # 4s x 2, a set of wires,two QDs, and stuff for the chains.
content.location: Just left of Crack In The Space Time Fabric, and the first line see as you come down the fixed line and turn left or south.

content.description:
Start by a patch of thorny shrubbery with easy moves on positive edges to gain the first bolt (a #2 would keep you off the deck if the unthinkable happened before clipping). Continue pulling big moves on small incuts, eventually hitting the arête below a blank patch of the face. Escape left around the corner to a finger crack and tiptoe up a slightly hollow flake using finger-size pieces for pro (make sure to use long runners) until you can reach the apex of the arête. Shuffle right below the roof on non-existent feet, aiming for a last bolt which appears completely off route to the right (rock quality dictated this placement). Pull a thuggy move to get above the roof and wander to the anchor via a wide hand crack.

A harder variation shoots straight up the face between the 2nd and 3rd bolt, avoiding the arête via a tricky sequence of hard moves on really small crimps. It meets up with the original line at the top of the arête and feels about 11c/+.

(edit: the direct line was done on lead and apparently goes at 11b. Guess I can't climb. I still feel that avoiding the arête

may

keep the grade at 11+)
content.protection:
5 bolts, a couple of finger-size pieces and a hand-size piece (#3) for the original line. Skip the small stuff and add one draw for the direct line.

Mandatory long runners for the small gear (consider a runner + a draw) as well as the last 2 bolts.

Chain anchor at the top.
content.location: WOTTM is the first line you'll see after coming down the fixed line into Pandora. Looks on the tower to your right for a clean concave face with a number of short crack features.

content.description: Very enjoyable arete and face climbing on steep edges.  Start in the corner to the right of the arete and work that arete to just past the third bolt where you cut left around a suspicious looking large block.  Clip the next bolt and pull the crux moving back right to the arete.  Move right of the arete on to edges of the adjacent face.  Here you start setting gear before heading left again toward the anchor that is shared with "The Last Shadow You Will Ever See."  We did a bit of cleaning here to make your adventure a bit less sketchy...see trundle video.
content.protection:
Four QDs, three runners, and an assortment small to medium cams.  There is also a need for one BD #4.  Chains and a quick link at the top.

vimeo.com/138342588
content.location: Just right of "The Last Shadow You Will Ever See."

climbs.name: The Last Shadow You Will Ever See

content.description:
Many BIG fun moves with great holds coming just when you need them most!  The really committing moves are between the second and third bolt.  Here you should be sewing up a sequence of small wires and cams prior to a big throw for a Thank God "Hand Pocket."  Pure fun!

If you wanted to work these moves out on a TR you could do the 9+ to the right which has the same anchor.
content.protection: Eight QDs, three runners, along with a set of small wires, and small to medium cams X 2 each.  This should get you to chains and a quick link where you will be rejoicing over this extraordinarily fun accomplishment.
content.location: Come down the chute on the fixed line and take a sharp left or SE turn to the obvious face.

climbs.name: Crack In The Space Time Fabric

content.description: As often it is in the Jungle, the crux is just before the chains.  The crack starts fingers then fists, then off-width/chimney (not hard and pro in the back) to the exciting last moves on an overhanging arete.
content.protection: BD .4 X 1, .5 X 1, .75 X 2, 1.0 X 2, 2.0 X 1, 3.0 X 2, 4.0 X 1, two QDs for the bolts,  and gear for the chains.  Two bolt anchor w/chain and quick links.  60 m will do.
content.location: As you come down the chute and fixed line go left or south about 20m.  Just left of The		Last Shadow You Will Ever See.

climbs.name: A Skxawng's Line
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Phyllis Suggett, and Alexie Mollard

content.description: I first thought I was above the line to the right when setting the anchor and preparing to clean. So like a moron, I inadvertently gave the best line to Alexis.  This left line however, turned out to be a good route.  It starts in a chimney, moves to face climbing before turning the arete and surmounting a head wall.  The arete moves are the most challenging.
content.protection: Four QDs for the bolts though you most likely will want to have runners to extend a few clips.  I used one BD #1 and #2 as well as a BD .4 (See Topo)  There are chains at the top with a quick link.
content.location: Descend the chute using the extended fixed line and then head right or north through some sketchy talus for a short distance.

climbs.name: Talus Knirschen
climbs.fa: Rich Magner, Roy Suggett & Alexis Mollard

content.description: Very small edges up high on the face make the moves 11b-ish but keeping the left hand on the arete rather than committing to the face will be more like 11a. Very demanding strength to weight ratio kind of thing on the face where a big reach to a very small edge is the crux move.
content.protection: Six QDs and a couple of runners, though a few medium sized cams might help too and that will get you to chains and a quick link.
content.location: This is the direct start to Wrath of the Talus Monster.  Come down the chute using the fixed line and head NW or right.  Climb the face and do not turn the arete or you would be doing the a fore mentioned WOTTM.
